messages.content: STM32 Hardware Questions and Answers goes here.

In this shematic there are dio clk pins also I saw t_dio, t_clk pins 
I was using pa13 swdio and pa14 swclk pins to programming the mcu`s 
So in stlink we are not using the pa13 and pa14 pins to program to the other mcu
Am I right ?
And what is this circuit for
t_ is for "target" - those are the pins used to communicate with that target.  The dio and clk are for programming the st-link device.
ST-Link have the option to measure the VCC of the target board (T_PWR), but in my DIY ST-Link I just ignore it completely.
thanks for this informations
I understood now How stlink is working
Great

there are too many pins on the schematic of original stlink circuit for communications jtag and swd
I want to know which pins are used for swd communication to program the mcu from stlink 
stm_jtck(swclk) and stm_jtms(swdio) for program to stm32f103 mcu  Im okey with this 
T_JTMS pin 27-25 this pins swdio 
 T_JTCK pin 26-15  this pins swclk 
so We use these T_JTMS and T_JTCK pins to program another processor via stm32f103?
Started a thread.

messages.content: Next generation STM32 Programmer - just ordered first version

Hello hope someone can help. I am planning on making a pan tilt platform for tracking purposes. I will have 2 servos + servo driver. My goal is to have my own position loop on a controller like STM32 G474. The servo drivers have their own velocity and current loop. The servos have their own absolute encoders. My question is: Should i get drivers with analog input or should i use CANopen?

Hard to tell without more data - best would be to test it out.  The important thing would be your target update-frequency.   I would guess analog _could_ be made faster but that might not be necessary.  CAN would be simpler wiring.

I am not that experienced with STM32 and no experience with CANopen. - My thought is that i would be to much of a gamble to try making a system based on CANopen. For analog i have this simple layout, only problem is getting the RS422 signal from the encoders made compatible with the G474re encoder inputs?
So far i have this:
more detailed
STM32 Programmer
Working flawlessly by the way
I like the pcb cover
Are those jtag/swd connectors expensive to manufacture?
Those are regular IDC SMD connectors.  No through-hole components.
Looks good "in the flesh". Any chance of a photo of the programmer PCB itself?
Does it reuse the chip from stlink?
Not sure what you mean by reuse.
Nice neat layout - I saw the kicad 3d version, but I always like to see in the flesh 🙂
What are the relatively large solder pads just under currentmakers.com for?

Solder jumper.  The original ST-Link devices measure the target device voltage and only flash if safe.  I find that more irritating than helpful, so by default it just "measure:" the 3.3V on the programmer itself 😉
Is that a Abacron crystal? I am making a usb to CAN adapter and I think I am using the same one, sucks its an extended component tho
If so - no - I am quite sure that one is a basic part 8 MHz - the only one available.
This is the one I used: https://jlcpcb.com/partdetail/AbraconLLC-ABM3_8_000MHZ_D2YT/C144380

messages.content: Hope it works for me. chatgpt said I needed 27 pF caps but they only had (in basic components) 22 or 30 so I went with 30
Well - I would recommend you read how to pick the right size rather than relying on ChatGPT.
It is not that complicated
https://jlcpcb.com/partdetail/YXC_CrystalOscillators-X50328MSB2GI/C115962 basic part and 350000 in stock - yours was extended and 7 in stock.

Cool!  However, why don't you break out the SWO and UART pins from what I assume is a ST-Link on top of the board.  Also I would have added a couple of jumpers to disconnect the st-link from the built-in target.  As is - you can't really use the ST-Link with an external target without breaking it of.
Thanks for ideas. I focused only the target on the board. I will make some changes on it
The Jolt Connect - STM32 Programmer & Debugger.  See https://stm32world.com/wiki/Jolt_Connect

messages.content: My stash of prototypes to be "productified" in coming months. Stay tuned.

Hey has anyone tried to integrate wifi using UART for STM32 MCU by using an ESP8266ex SoC? If yes then please shed some light on below:

I was actually looking to understand on how to make a custom PCB as my end goal is to send and receive data using Wifi Feature of the ESP8266ex by utilising the AT Commands

I am really struggling to create a PCB Design for the same

I haven't done this, but I have used an ESP32 to control an STM32 using the SWD protocol.  What specifically are you finding difficult?  This should be a straightforward layout with the UART pins of the two MCUs connected to each other, ensuring you connect TX from one to RX of the other, and vice versa.

Hey thanks for the reply,
I am actually struggling to setup the IO pins such GPIO0, GPIO2 and MTDO as from ex8266ex are not flashed with the AT Binary so while working on the schematics i am slightly confused as to how to pull them low for flashing when needed, and other keeping them at normal state to make the MCU function normally.

But actually I changed my design to use the ESP32-S3 for the whole project

there's a lot of schematics around for a dual transistor circuit to use the serial DTR/etc lines to automatically pull the right things low for programming th ESP.  I'd suggest picking a user focused breakout board, finding it's schematic, and copying that.

This is something from 10 years ago, where an ESP-12F (ESP8266 inside) were used and programming over USB was done. HOWEVER, it has some problems. The 1N4148 voltage drop is too high to guarantee tghe RESET. So, this doesn't work with every produced unit. But if you drop the WatchDog and remove the diode, this should work (at least with the programmer back then).
The ESP-01S is made for this and comes preloaded with the AT firmware.
Testing the usb to canbus adapters I made

v2 works perfect \:)
v2.1 is not that happy.... While this one flashed without problems I am getting buffer errors when using CAN. I did use another package for the CAN transceiver but it should work the same. 
Only thing that's different is that it has a ground plane under it which should have plenty of vias for thermal dissipation and I problably didnt do well enough. Well guess I am going back to the so8 TJA1051T/3 for v2.3 because that one works flawlessly
Engineering rule number - I think 2 or 3 - if it works, don't fix it 😉
hahahaha should be number #1 but I got seduced by a slicker package
anyway if people are interested in the cad files they can be found [here](<https://github.com/11philip22/candleLight-v2>)
NEVERMIND v2.1 FREAKING WORKS 🎉🎉🎉🎉🎉🎉
I forgot I had swapped GND on the big terminal block around
I believe number 1 is: "read the bloody datasheet"
I also need to switch from STM32F072C8T6 to STM32F072CBT6 because jlc doesnt have enough C8's So have some reading to do for sure
And I have to turn this board into the shape of kitt from night rider for a convention badge
